title: The Importance of Sleep for Teenagers
original:
Teenagers today are often sleep-deprived due to busy school schedules, social activities, and screen time before bed. However, sleep plays a vital role in both mental and physical development. Experts recommend that teens get at least 8 to 10 hours of sleep each night, yet many are getting far less.

A lack of sleep can lead to problems with concentration, mood, and academic performance. Long-term sleep deprivation is also linked to more serious health issues, such as obesity, depression, and a weakened immune system. Developing good sleep habits—like keeping a regular bedtime and avoiding screens late at night—can significantly improve overall well-being.
simplified:
Many teenagers don’t sleep enough. They are busy with school, friends, and using phones at night. But sleep is very important for the body and mind. Doctors say teenagers should sleep for 8 to 10 hours, but many do not.

If teenagers don’t sleep well, they may feel tired and sad. They may not do well in school. If this continues, it can cause health problems like getting sick more easily. It’s a good idea to sleep at the same time every night and not look at phones before bed.

questions.question: What is the main idea of this passage?
options: Teenagers need more free time
Phones are bad for your eyes
Not enough sleep can cause problems
Teens should eat better
questions.answer: Not enough sleep can cause problems
questions.hint: 第一パラグラフの全体の意味を読み取ろう。子供はもっと『　　』すべき？

questions.question: What does the word "deprived" most likely mean in the sentence: 'Teenagers today are often sleep-deprived due to busy school schedules...'
options: full of
lacking or missing
excited
worried
questions.hint: この言葉は良い意味？悪い意味？眠れていないということは…？

questions.question: According to the passage, what are possible long-term effects of not sleeping enough?
options: Improved energy and mood
Lower risk of disease
Obesity and a weak immune system
Better memory and stronger muscles
questions.answer: Obesity and a weak immune system
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフのリストに注目しよう。

questions.question: What does this sentence mean? 'Developing good sleep habits—like keeping a regular bedtime and avoiding screens late at night—can significantly improve overall well-being.'
options: Teenagers should stop sleeping to use their phones
Being healthy has nothing to do with sleep
Regular habits like sleep and avoiding screens help people stay healthy
Teens only need to eat well, not sleep well
questions.answer: Regular habits like sleep and avoiding screens help people stay healthy
questions.hint: この文の例（就寝時間やスマホ）から意味を考えてみよう。

questions.question: True or False: Doctors say teens should sleep at least 6 hours each night.
questions.hint: 第一パラグラフにある数字を見てみよう。

title: The Role of Music in Our Lives
original:
Music is an important part of every culture. It brings people together and expresses emotions. People listen to music when they are happy, sad, or need motivation.

In many countries, traditional music is played at festivals and ceremonies. Modern music connects global audiences. Whether it's classical, pop, or hip-hop, music helps people feel understood and inspired.
simplified:
Music is important in all cultures. It helps people share feelings. People listen to music when they are happy, sad, or need energy.

In many places, people play traditional music at festivals. New music styles are popular around the world. Music makes people feel good and connected.

questions.question: What is the main idea of this passage?
options: Music makes people hungry.
Music is only for young people.
Music connects people and expresses feelings.
Music is only traditional.
questions.answer: Music connects people and expresses feelings.
questions.hint: 第一パラグラフの意味を考えよう。なぜ人は音楽を聞く？

questions.question: What does 'motivation' most likely mean?
options: A type of music
Feeling tired
A reason to act or try
A festival name
questions.answer: A reason to act or try
questions.hint: 音楽を聞いて元気が出るということは…？

questions.question: According to the passage, how is traditional music used?
options: To connect with global audiences
At festivals and ceremonies
Only in schools
To make people sleepy
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフを読んでみよう。

questions.question: What does this sentence mean? 'Whether it's classical, pop, or hip-hop, music helps people feel understood and inspired.'
options: Only classical music is emotional
All music helps people feel something
Pop music is better than hip-hop
Music is confusing
questions.answer: All music helps people feel something
questions.hint: クラシックでもヒップホップでも…どうなる？

questions.question: True or False: Music is not important in ceremonies.
options: True
False
questions.hint: traditional music の使い方を見てみよう。

title: Uncertainty in Parenting
original:
Parenting is full of uncertainty. Many books promise to teach how to raise a successful child, but they often reflect only the author's own experience. Each child is different, and what works for one may not work for another.

Parents must solve problems in real-time—soothing a crying baby or handling a child's tantrum—without the help of a manual. They often feel unprepared, like amateurs learning as they go. There is no perfect path, only the desire to do what’s best.
simplified:
There are many books about how to raise children. But each child is different, and the books don't always help. What worked for one parent may not work for others.

Parents have to take care of problems like crying or changing diapers right away. They can't look at books in those moments. Parents learn by doing. There is no one correct way to raise children.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: A. Parenting is easy if you read the right books.
B. Every parent should follow expert advice.
C. Parenting is full of uncertainty and personal experience.
D. Children behave the same in most situations.
questions.hint: 第一パラグラフの全体の意味を読み取ろう。子供はもっと『　　』すべき？

questions.question: What does 'real-time' most likely mean in the passage?
options: A. At a later time.
B. As things happen.
C. After reading a book.
D. Without thinking.
questions.hint: 『They must solve problems in real-time』と書かれているので、文脈から意味を考えてみよう。

questions.question: True or False: The passage says that parenting books always help.
questions.hint: 本文には『they often reflect only the author's own experience』とある。

questions.question: What does 'like amateurs learning as they go' mean?
options: A. Parents are professionals with lots of training.
B. Parents study books before taking action.
C. Parents make mistakes and improve over time.
D. Parents do nothing when children cry.
questions.hint: amateur は初心者という意味。文の流れから、何を伝えたいか考えよう。

questions.question: Why does the passage say there is no perfect path?
options: A. Because all children follow the same rules.
B. Because parents never make mistakes.
C. Because each parenting experience is different.
D. Because parenting books are always wrong.
questions.hint: なぜ『there is no perfect path』と言っているのか、直後の文に注目。

title: The Meaning of Knowing People
original:
In the past, we knew people by their faces, voices, and daily actions. We recognized neighbors in the street, talked to classmates in person, and knew what our friends liked and did.

Today, things have changed. We often interact online, sometimes without seeing a face or hearing a real voice. We may not know if the person truly exists or what they do in real life. While we can connect with more people now, it’s harder to feel that we truly know them.
simplified:
Before, we knew people by seeing them and talking to them. We could see our neighbors and friends and understand what they liked.

Now, we often talk online. We do not see people’s faces or hear their voices. Sometimes, we do not even know if they are real. It is easy to meet many people, but it is hard to really know them.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: A. People no longer care about friendships.
B. Online communication is always better.
C. Knowing people has become harder in modern times.
D. We should only meet people online.
questions.hint: この文章が一番大事：『While we can connect with more people now, it’s harder to feel that we truly know them.』

questions.question: What does 'interact' mean in the passage?
options: A. Talk or do things with someone
B. Look for someone’s name
C. Argue online
D. Send photos to others
questions.hint: 『interact online』と書いてあるので、意味を考えてみよう。

questions.question: True or False: The author says modern ways of communication are always bad.
questions.hint: 著者は modern ways of communication を否定しているかどうか、全体を見て考えてみよう。

questions.question: What does 'We don’t know their faces, their voices, or even if they are real.' mean?
options: A. Everyone online is pretending.
B. We never hear voices online.
C. We often don’t know people’s physical features or if they are real.
D. The internet hides all information about people.
questions.hint: ここで言いたいのは、顔や声など『physical features』が分からないということ。

questions.question: Why is it harder to feel we know people today?
options: A. Because we only meet people face to face.
B. Because we can no longer talk to people.
C. Because we interact with many people only online.
D. Because we see too many neighbors daily.
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフを読んで、なぜ『truly know』するのが難しいのかを考えよう。

glossary.definition: to talk or do things with others
a person who lives near you
to join or link with someone

title: Preserving Democracy in Changing Times
original:
In recent years, many countries have seen a decline in democratic values. People are losing trust in elections, political leaders, and the media. Some governments restrict freedom of speech or weaken the independence of courts. These actions slowly erode the foundation of democracy, even when they are done through legal means. When citizens stop paying attention or believe their voices no longer matter, democracy begins to fail.

To preserve democracy, active participation is essential. Voting is important, but it is only the beginning. Citizens must stay informed, speak out against injustice, and support institutions that protect rights and freedoms. Democracy is not just a system of government. It is not something simply given to us — it was gained through the struggles and sacrifices of many people. When we defend truth, fairness, and accountability, we honor their efforts and help keep democracy alive for future generations.
simplified:
In some countries, people are losing trust in democracy. They do not believe in elections or leaders. Some governments stop free speech or control the courts. These things make democracy weaker. If people stop caring or think their voices do not matter, democracy can break.

To keep democracy strong, people must take action. Voting is important, but it is not enough. People should stay informed, speak up when things are unfair, and protect human rights. Democracy was not always here. Many people fought and died for it. We must protect it for the future.

questions.question: What is the main idea of this passage?
options: A. People no longer need to vote.
B. Democracy is safe around the world.
C. Democracy must be protected by the people.
D. Governments always protect people’s rights.
questions.hint: 第一パラグラフと第二パラグラフのつながりに注目しよう。

questions.question: What does the word "sacrifices" most likely mean in the sentence: 'It was gained through the struggles and sacrifices of many people.'
options: A. Money people gave to the government
B. Things people gave up or lost for something important
C. Mistakes people made in the past
D. Traditions from older times
questions.hint: 文の流れを考えよう。democracy を得るために、人々は何をした？

questions.question: True or False: Some governments today try to weaken democracy using legal methods.
questions.hint: 『These actions slowly erode the foundation of democracy』の意味を考えよう。

questions.question: What does this sentence mean? 'Democracy is not something simply given to us — it was gained through the struggles and sacrifices of many people.'
options: A. Democracy is free and easy to keep.
B. Democracy was created by the government alone.
C. People had to fight and suffer to build democracy.
D. Most people do not care about democracy.
questions.hint: struggles や sacrifices の意味とつながりに注目しよう。

questions.question: Why does the passage say we must defend truth, fairness, and accountability?
options: A. To follow government rules
B. To win elections more easily
C. To make media more popular
D. To protect democracy and honor people who fought for it
questions.hint: なぜ『truth, fairness, and accountability』を守る必要があるのか、最後の文を読んで考えよう。

title: Equality and Fairness
original:
Equality means giving everyone the same resources or opportunities. It sounds fair at first, but in reality, people have different needs. For example, imagine three people of different heights trying to watch a baseball game over a fence. If each person is given the same size box to stand on, the shortest person still cannot see the game. In some societies, this kind of one-size-fits-all approach is criticized as excessive equalitarianism.

Fairness, or equity, means giving people the support they actually need to have the same chance of success. In the baseball example, the shortest person gets the tallest box, the middle person a smaller box, and the tallest person none at all. Now, everyone can enjoy the view equally.
simplified:
Equality means giving the same help to everyone. It sounds fair, but people have different needs. Imagine three people of different heights watching a baseball game over a fence. If each person gets the same box, the shortest person still cannot see. In some places, this problem is called "too much equal treatment."

Fairness, or equity, means giving help based on need. The shortest person gets the tallest box, the middle person gets a smaller box, and the tallest person gets no box. Now, everyone can watch the game.

questions.question: What is the main idea of this passage?
options: A. Equality and fairness are the same
B. Fairness means giving help based on need
C. Everyone should get the same box
D. Fairness is always unfair
questions.hint: 第一パラグラフと第二パラグラフの違いに注目しよう。

questions.question: What does the word "equity" most likely mean in the passage?
options: A. Being rich
B. Treating people based on needs
C. Playing baseball
D. Measuring height
questions.hint: 公平とは何か？野球の例を思い出そう。

questions.question: True or False: In the equality example, even the shortest person can see the game.
questions.hint: 第一パラグラフの野球の例を読んでみよう。

questions.question: What does this sentence mean? "In some societies, this kind of one-size-fits-all approach is criticized as excessive equalitarianism."
options: A. Some think giving the same to everyone can be a problem
B. Everyone agrees equality is always good
C. People want to watch more baseball games
D. Equality and fairness mean the same thing
questions.hint: excessive equalitarianism の意味を考えてみよう。

questions.question: Why does the fairness example give different boxes to people?
options: A. So everyone can see the game
B. So everyone can be the same height
C. So the tallest person can get more help
D. So the game will be more exciting
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフの目的に注目しよう。

title: Parenting and Cooking: A Shared Responsibility
original:
Today, men who engage in parenting and cooking are respected and valued. These tasks are often seen as natural for women, but in fact no one is born with such skills. Cooking and raising children must be learned through practice. For many years, women have had more chances to learn, simply because men stayed away. As a result, women often became more skilled, while men missed out. If fathers continue to avoid these roles, they will not only create an unfair burden for women but also limit their own growth.

Parenting and cooking are not simple duties. They are creative and enjoyable experiences. Cooking means thinking carefully: what food is left in the refrigerator, what the family enjoys, and how to prepare tomorrow’s lunch. Parenting means sharing joy, solving problems, and teaching children by example. These activities require attention, patience, and imagination. Men should take part not only to support women, but also for themselves. By learning these skills, men become more capable, and the whole family becomes stronger and happier.
simplified:
Today, men who take care of children and cook are respected. Parenting and cooking need skills, and no one is born with them. Women are not born knowing how to cook or raise children. They learn by doing. Men must also learn. If men stay away from these jobs, their partners will become better, but the men will not.

Cooking and parenting are enjoyable and give joy. Cooking is creative: thinking about what food is left, what the family likes, and how to make a good meal. Fathers can spend time with children, and children can learn from them. Men should do more, not only to help women, but also for themselves. By learning these skills, men can grow, and families can become fair and happy.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: Parenting and cooking are natural skills for women.
Men should share parenting and cooking because these skills are learned and valuable.
Cooking is only about using leftovers.
Fathers should avoid household work to grow faster.
questions.answer: Men should share parenting and cooking because these skills are learned and valuable.
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフの全体の意味を考えよう。「Men should take part … for themselves.」

questions.question: What does the word "burden" most nearly mean in: "create an unfair burden for women"?
options: A happy surprise
A heavy load or responsibility
A quick decision
A simple tool
questions.hint: 男性が避けるほど女性の仕事量が増える＝重荷。

questions.question: True or False: The passage says women are born with special parenting and cooking skills.
questions.hint: 第一パラグラフに「no one is born with such skills」とある。

questions.question: What does this sentence mean? "If fathers continue to avoid these roles, they will … limit their own growth."
options: They will gain many new skills.
They will have more time for hobbies.
They will miss chances to learn and improve.
They will make family life more equal.
questions.answer: They will miss chances to learn and improve.
questions.hint: limit their own growth＝成長の機会を失う。

questions.question: Why is cooking called creative in the passage?
options: Because it is only about cleaning the fridge.
Because it requires thinking about leftovers, family likes, and future meals.
Because it doesn’t need any planning.
Because it is natural for women.
questions.answer: Because it requires thinking about leftovers, family likes, and future meals.
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフの『Cooking means thinking carefully…』を読もう。

title: The Power of Guessing in Reading and Listening
original:
When you read a passage or listen to someone speak, it is natural to find words you do not know. Many learners believe they must understand every single word. However, this is not true. Good readers and listeners often guess the meaning from context. They look at the other words, the sentence, or the situation, and make a smart guess. This skill is even more important in real-life communication, where there is no dictionary to help you.

You can also guess from the topic. For example, if the title is about smartphones and young people, you can predict it might be about using smartphones too much and the negative effects. If your guess is correct, you will understand faster. If it is wrong, you can quickly switch to a new guess. Focusing too much on difficult words can slow you down and make you lose the main idea. Even native speakers do not know every word, but they still understand by guessing. Developing this skill makes you more confident and helps you enjoy English without fear.
simplified:
When you read or listen, you often see words you do not know. Many students think they must know all words, but this is not true. Good readers and listeners guess the meaning. They use other words, the sentence, or the situation. Guessing helps in real life, because you cannot always use a dictionary.

You can also guess from the topic. For example, if the title is about smartphones and young people, you can guess it is about too much smartphone use and problems. If your guess is right, it helps. If it is wrong, you can change your guess. If you stop at every hard word, you will forget the main idea. Even native speakers do not know all words. They also guess. Guessing makes you confident and helps you enjoy English more.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: A. Students must know every word to understand English.
B. Guessing from context and topic is important in reading and listening.
C. Using a dictionary well helps you to learn more.
D. Native speakers never guess word meanings.
questions.hint: 第一パラグラフと第二パラグラフを合わせて考えよう。「guessing」が大事。

questions.question: What does "context" most likely mean in the passage?
options: A. A difficult dictionary word
B. The situation and other words around
C. A secret message
D. A special test
questions.hint: 「They look at the other words, the sentence, or the situation」とある。

questions.question: According to the passage, if the topic is about smartphones and young people, what can you guess?
options: A. It will explain how to build a smartphone.
B. It might be about using smartphones too much and negative effects.
C. It describes how young people pay for their phone.
D. It will illustrate the history of mobile phones.
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフの例を読んでみよう。

questions.question: What does this sentence mean? “Focusing too much on difficult words can slow you down and make you lose the main idea.”
options: A. Looking at hard words helps you go faster.
B. If you stop too long at hard words, you miss the important message.
C. The main idea is always in the dictionary.
D. Native speakers focus on every single word.
questions.hint: 「slow you down」と「lose the main idea」の意味を考えよう。

questions.question: Why do even native speakers need to guess?
options: A. Because they are not good at English.
B. Because they also do not know every word.
C. Because they never read books.
D. Because they forget to use a dictionary.
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフの「Even native speakers do not know every word」を読もう。

title: Finding What You Want to Do
original:
Many people find what they want to do in life quite early. They decide to become a lawyer, a doctor, a business person, or an athlete, and then they work hard to reach that goal. For them, the path looks clear, and their studies feel directly connected to their dreams.

However, others find it difficult to decide. They want to study for their future, but if they doubt their choice, it is hard to concentrate. Some just keep searching for the 'right' job forever, without deciding. For these students, finishing school is itself a good path, because more knowledge and experience can open new opportunities. Even if you don’t know what to do yet, learning more can guide you toward a future that fits you.
simplified:
Many people know what job they want. They want to be a doctor, a lawyer, a business person, or an athlete. They study hard for that dream.

But some students do not know. If they are not sure, it is hard to study well. Some keep looking for the answer forever. For them, finishing school is very important. Learning more gives them new ideas and new chances. Even if you don’t know your job now, keep learning. School can help you find the way.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: A. Everyone should become a lawyer or doctor.
B. Finishing school can give you hints and guidance if you don’t know your job yet.
C. You cannot study if you don’t know your job.
D. School is not important for finding work.
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフの「finishing school is itself a good path…」に注目。

questions.question: What does "concentrate" most likely mean in the passage?
options: A. To stop learning
B. To focus attention
C. To change jobs
D. To feel tired
questions.hint: 「hard to concentrate」とあるので、studying との関係を考えよう。

questions.question: According to the passage, why is finishing school good for people who don’t know their job yet?
options: A. Because school gives money
B. Because finishing school makes parents happy
C. Because learning more opens new chances
D. Because everyone becomes a lawyer after school
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフの最後にある「new opportunities」に注目。

questions.question: What does this sentence mean? “Even if you don’t know what to do yet, learning more can guide you toward a future that fits you.”
options: A. Only people with a clear dream should learn.
B. Studying can help you discover a good future, even without a plan now.
C. The future is always clear for students.
D. Dreams and studying are not connected.
questions.hint: 「guide you toward a future」＝将来へ導く。

questions.question: True or False: It is important to search for the right job forever.
questions.hint: 第二パラグラフの「Some just keep searching forever, without deciding」とあるが、それを大事だとは言っていない。
